turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- summarize -- (Inaudible) I don't know --

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, but I would like to address one sentence to Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

I think he asked the pointed question as to whether we question the accuracy of Judge Forman's statement which is pointed out in which in his opinion, which he said not only was the petitioner deprived of the cherished American rights but the dignity of his legal profession was demeaned and so forth.
The fact of the matter, that in the hearing, there never was any dispute about that.
In fact, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon, the assistant prosecutor went down and met Mr. Palmieri.
Mr. Palmieri said, “I'd like to see Cicenia can I hear him out.
Mr. Palmieri -- Mr. McCune (ph), the assistant prosecutor politely told, "Just as soon as we complete our investigation" although there was no denial about it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Would you be good enough to state on behalf of New Jersey why -- how you justify denying to a fellow your assessment up for a serious crime access to or rather the opportunity for his lawyer, to have access to his client.
What is the -- what is the justification for that in your view?

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Mr. Justice Frankfurter, the rule of law in New Jersey that a lawyer is not entitled to see his client during the time between arrest and arraignment.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understand that rule of law.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: That is the reason.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, but that is --

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: It's the rule.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I want to know what the reason is not from the point of view of whether it's more or less convenient but from the point of view of that ultimate question, whether that is such an unfairness that it may be challenged under the Fourteenth -- under the Due Process Clause because that's the only question we have here, not general consideration whether it's convenient or inconvenient, desirable or undesirable at least speaking for myself.
There's an ultimate question of whether this come forth with the kind of treatment that anybody you and I would like to have under similar circumstances.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Well, I'd say we stood by New Jersey law not to hold this --.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, but you're now here in the United States Supreme Court Law and have to decide this question.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: You haven't said so yet.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, but that's why I am asking.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: You haven't said so yet.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If I were in Jersey, that would be a perfect answer.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: That was our position.
Now, if you want to interpret the Sixth Amendment, to me --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I won't do that.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Anytime.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I won't do that myself.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: I've been a practicing criminal lawyer for many years.
And I know -- let's look at it practically.
I told this to the Circuit Court of Appeals.
There's only one reason why a lawyer wants to get in there to see his client at a time when he is being interrogated.
Well, there you don't even have to talk to him.
I've been a lawyer.
I want to -- I've been in that same position many a time.
I want to see you.
I don't care to talk to, just let me see you.
Why?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: When I see him I'm going to say to him, “Sshh”.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is he entitled to "Sshh" --

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, when he's not under oath --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is he entitled to that?

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: He's not under oath.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But he's entitled to keep quiet?

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: He's not under oath.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is he entitled to keep quiet?

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: The man is trying to tell a story and the police are trying to get it from a man who learned the truth.
Where would our law enforcement be today, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, if in every case a lawyer comes bouncing in and says, “I want to see him.”
That's all there told.
(Inaudible) Mr. Justice Frankfurter, what are we supposed to do, push everything aside, Your Honor here, come on in.
Why, you show him immediately when the thing would have come -- there was no rough stuff used.
Immediately after the confession with -- maybe go ahead and see him and he saw him every minute that time from that time forward.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But he didn't see him until you got through with him, did he?

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Through with him?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Until you got through with him, in this thing that -- (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Well, when I say through with him --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I didn't mean --

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: -- don't misinterpret that word.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I -- I didn't mean to have it to be -- to be afraid.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Yes, when they completed their --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I mean he didn't see him until you finished, by you I mean the --

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- lawful -- the law enforcement (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Until you got through getting out of him what you wanted, is that right?

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: That's it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Isn't it?

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I noticed you relied on Groban.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I noticed you relied on the Groban case, decided in this Court.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Groban?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why did you do that?

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: That's the case of the Fire Marshal having a hearing in which certain witnesses refused to be sworn and refused to testify?
Yes, I read that case, Your Honor.
And in that case, what was the conclusion?
Do you use exactly these words?
There's a man, a witness before a grand jury entitled to the assistance of counsel?

And for the same reason, when this Fire Marshal was trying to find out the circumstances and the facts upon which to face a criminal charge of arson or whatever the Court or the fire might have been, that is Groban.
I relied upon it, yes Mr. Justice Black.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Caruso.
Mr. Debevoise, you may proceed.

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: If it please the Court, I have nothing further to add into my main argument.
I -- in rebuttal I think the main argument covered what I had to say.
I did want to add -- answer Mr. Justice Frankfurter's question as to the opinion of the Appellate Division of New Jersey in this case on appeal.
That is on the habeas corpus appeal.
That opinion was not reported.
It was by stipulation included in the record below.

Judge Forman found -- this is on page 14 of the record that the Appellate Division decided petitioner's claim of denial of right to counsel on the merits, I -- that's to hold inferentially at least that there is no taint of illegality touching that confession.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: In that case, you're (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: The habeas corpus, yes.
That is true, Your Honor, yes.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: So, all the opinions were in that trial.

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: That would be true, Your Honor.
And it would be in -- in the record on this case, though not in the transcript that that was not -- that finding was not disputed or it was not an issue.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But the Appellate Division that came here on certiorari -- I don't need to feel with the merits, but the appeal's benefit throughout the appeal is not perfected and -- and that is it was perfected out of time.

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: That was part of the holding, Your Honor and then the Court went ahead to decide it on the merits.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, I -- I understand that.
But if it was out of time, and therefore, that would be an end of the matter.
How can it -- what's the bearing of that on habeas corpus in federal courts?

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the -- as Judge Forman found below the Court did rule on the merits and therefore, it -- Judge Forman proceeded on the merits in that case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, I know he did that but I'm asking you what -- what business a federal court has to deal with the merits of -- of appeal in the state court which was out of time it to have been passed on by the State Court, which you could had been in time, could have been dealt with by this Court on the merits as of that time.

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, as I -- if I understand your question correctly I -- this is directed to the habeas corpus proceedings in the state court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is correct.
That is my question.

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: And the -- I -- I was -- my answer today that it was decided on the merits in the Appellate Division in the state court.
I -- it was -- then went to the Supreme Court of New Jersey where it was -- a review was not granted because of -- they've declined to grant a petition to proceed in forma pauperis.
It then came to this Court on certiorari which was denied.
And therefore, I -- the state court treated it as if it were in time, decided it on the merits and proceeded on that basis.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Treated it as though it were in time.

My point is that if a state court denies the case on the ground which rests on a state ground, how can you whip the devil around the stump and then say, “Well, the federal court can assume it was passed on the merits.”

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: Your Honor, if it were on the state grounds alone, that would -- I -- I confess you're right.
That would bar us from proceeding further.
In this case, we submit it was on the federal ground that the decision was decided and that was the finding of the federal court below.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If it can rest on a state ground, we can't review it.

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: If that were the only ground, Your Honor, yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, that isn't so.
If a state decision rests on both the federal ground and the state ground and can rest on the state ground, then we cannot review it.

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, there are decisions to that effect.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, not decision.
You think that there're some decisions one way and some decisions the other way.
Insofar as I know there are no decisions here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand what you say is and maybe I'm wrong.
If it has no materiality but I understand what you say is that the state court could have declined to consider the case and decide it because it was out of time.
They also had the power to waive that if they so desire to consider the merits.
And you say that's what they did.

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
They proceeded on the merit.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Debevoise, before you sit down, I would just like to say that the Court has informed that you came into this case by assignment of the -- in the lower court.

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And you've carried over that obligation as you saw it into this Court?

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We're very grateful to you, sir for -- for having done it.
We're always comforted when lawyers are willing to give their time and energy in defending the rights of an impecunious defendant.
So, we thank you, sir for -- for your representation here.
And Mr. Caruso, we thank you for the vigor with which you have represented your State and also for your frankness in the entire proceeding.

turn.speaker: c_william_caruso
turn.label: Mr. C. William Caruso
turn.text: Thank you very, very much.

turn.speaker: dickinson_r_debevoise
turn.label: Mr. Dickinson R. Debevoise
turn.text: I consider an honor to be permitted to bring the case here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you.
